Every natural number can be expressed as an even number (the sum of two identical numbers) or an odd number (2 times an integer plus 1).

type: âˆ€ (n : â„•), Even n âˆ¨ Odd n
name: Nat.even_or_odd
docString: Every natural number can be expressed as an even number (the sum of two identical numbers) or an odd number (2 times an integer plus 1).

This theorem states that for all natural numbers `n`, the product of `n` and `n - 1` is an even number. In mathematical terms, this theorem can be written as: "âˆ€ n âˆˆ â„•, n*(n - 1) is even." Here, a number is considered even if it can be expressed as twice another number, in this case, n*(n - 1) = 2*r for some `r`.

type: âˆ€ (n : â„•), Even (n * (n - 1))
name: Nat.even_mul_self_pred
docString: This theorem states that for all natural numbers `n`, the product of `n` and `n - 1` is an even number. In mathematical terms, this theorem can be written as: "âˆ€ n âˆˆ â„•, n*(n - 1) is even." Here, a number is considered even if it can be expressed as twice another number, in this case, n*(n - 1) = 2*r for some `r`.

The convolution of two even functions is also even.

type:
âˆ€ {ð•œ : Type uð•œ} {G : Type uG} {E : Type uE} {E' : Type uE'} {F : Type uF} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E]
  [inst_1 : NormedAddCommGroup E'] [inst_2 : NormedAddCommGroup F] {f : G â†’ E} {g : G â†’ E'} {x : G}
  [inst_3 : NontriviallyNormedField ð•œ] [inst_4 : NormedSpace ð•œ E] [inst_5 : NormedSpace ð•œ E'] [inst_6 : NormedSpace ð•œ F]
  (L : E â†’L[ð•œ] E' â†’L[ð•œ] F) [inst_7 : MeasurableSpace G] {Î¼ : MeasureTheory.Measure G} [inst_8 : NormedSpace â„ F]
  [inst_9 : AddCommGroup G] [inst_10 : MeasureTheory.Measure.IsAddLeftInvariant Î¼]
  [inst_11 : MeasureTheory.Measure.IsNegInvariant Î¼] [inst_12 : MeasurableNeg G] [inst_13 : MeasurableAdd G],
  (âˆ€áµ (x : G) âˆ‚Î¼, f (-x) = f x) â†’ (âˆ€áµ (x : G) âˆ‚Î¼, g (-x) = g x) â†’ convolution f g L (-x) = convolution f g L x
name: convolution_neg_of_neg_eq
docString: The convolution of two even functions is also even.

For all natural numbers `n`, the product of `n` and `n-1` is an even number. Equivalently, the product of two consecutive natural numbers is an even number.

type: âˆ€ (n : â„•), Even (n * (n - 1))
name: Nat.even_mul_self_pred
docString: For all natural numbers `n`, the product of `n` and `n-1` is an even number. Equivalently, the product of two consecutive natural numbers is an even number.

The theorem `Even.mod_even` states that for any two natural numbers `n` and `a`, if both `n` and `a` are even (i.e., each can be expressed as twice some other natural number), then the remainder when `n` is divided by `a` is also even.

type: âˆ€ {n a : â„•}, Even n â†’ Even a â†’ Even (n % a)
name: Even.mod_even
docString: The theorem `Even.mod_even` states that for any two natural numbers `n` and `a`, if both `n` and `a` are even (i.e., each can be expressed as twice some other natural number), then the remainder when `n` is divided by `a` is also even.
